Process

Researching

Earth Day is probably the most well-known civic observance in the world. Earth Day Network (EDN) is an organization that educates the public about climate change and the importance of sustainability. With its 45th anniversary coming up this month, they have launched its 2014 campaign website themed “It’s Our Turn to Lead.”
Despite its influence, the original site was very basic, something that provided Earth Day 2014 with a web presence and not much more. The site is very difficult to navigate, and it's very confusing to the users as what actions to take.

Goals for the redesign

1. Make the site more appealing to its younger audience.
2. Use context to compel users to action.
3. Keep the content clear and concise from beginning to end.
4. Improve UI’s with a more consistent look and feel to make things be more consistent.

The project focused on designing the pages that are most important to the Site and thus empower the user to take action: Home, About, Program, Find an event, and Organize an event.
You can see the proposal here

Restructuring Content

As usual, I started by listing the content that would be included on the page that I was redesigning.

Sketching page layouts

The original website really looked horrible. This time, I wanted to give it a more modern presentation, and also making sure to keep the content clear and concise from beginning to end.
You can see the larger version of these sketches here


Wireframes for Home and About

Based on the feedback, I came up with these Wireframes. Typically, the home page should have a continuous and sequential flow of content (what->why->how). I wanted it to present the information in a simple yet compelling way. I also wanted to add buttons to make things more accessible. The user would be able to jump to other pages very easily, through either these buttons or the main navigation.
You can see the larger version of these Wireframes here

Creating StyleTiles

I had an idea in mind for some brighter colors. I explored some different options which felt pleasant to look at but not so “in your face.”

Early StyleTiles





Final StyleTile



Creating Mockups for Home and About

You can see the larger version of these Mockups here

Early Mockups

I created mockups to understand more of what it would look like.

Final Mockups

Here are the final mockups for the homepage and the about page. Based on the feedback, I removed the speech bubbles. A subtle, semi-transparent background can lend significant visual interest.

Coding HTML & CSS

Once settled on the idea, I started coding HTML & CSS for the site. I also used Bourbon & Sass for a better and faster web development.

Adding media queries in CSS to make page responsive.

I used a percentage based grid that adapts to smaller screens. All column classes would adjust to 100% width when viewed on mobile.

Designing Logo and Icons

It took me a while to design the logo and icon set. I first had an idea for a typographic logo. But when I put it together, the logo really didn’t feel right. I realized that a good logo should be simple and should be recognizable. I had the up arrow sign in my head, and sketched concepts for those. The final logo and icon designs here, were simplified and adhere to the new style.



Adding jQuery-dependent plug-ins

I utilized the following 3 Java-script plugins to enhance the UX of the Site:
  • Responsive-nav: http://responsive-nav.com/
  • Timer: http://codepen.io/chriscoyier/pen/vbsHK
  • Modernizr.js for progressive enhancement and graceful fall-back
